title.narrative: Child Survival: Breastfeeding Counseling (BFC) Blended Learning Course for Private Midwives in Jakarta

description.narrative: Mercy Corps' recent Maternal Nutrition Survey (2012) revealed that less than 2% of pregnant women in West Jakarta reported having received standard information shared with them during breastfeeding counseling (e.g. skin to skin contact, breastcrawls, breastfeeding on demand, breastmilk expression for working mothers, etc). Mercy Corps aims to develop a blend of in-class, active learning, clinical practice and self-assessment methods for private midwives to gain competencies in the much needed breastfeeding counseling practice so more Indonesian newborns can benefit from early skin-to-skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding for six months, and celebrate their first birthday healthy. Mercy Corps will work in partnership with Health[e]Foundation to develop, conduct and document this blended learning course for breastfeeding counseling in Jakarta.

This project will be part of the larger ongoing USAID-funded Child Survival program in Jakarta, namely Hati Kami. The goal of Hati Kami is to promote, support, and protect the mother-child dyad for a healthy start among Jakarta's poor residents.
Hati Kami has 2 Objectives: 1. Improved maternal child care and nutrition practices of mothers from pregnancy through the first 6 months of life, and 2. Improved quality of maternal, newborn and infant services.
The Johnson & Johnson APCC 2013 funding will contribute to Objective 2 by supporting 30 private midwives in Jakarta gain breastfeeding counseling competencies through the blended learning method by the end of 2013.
